data.title: Re indenting feature is missing.
Task.json is not identified if root directory is opened instead of project directory.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I am experiencing this rather unusual behaviour:

I have simple tasks in my task file currently located at:
![screen shot 2017-03-22 at 9 44 51 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13655874/24181937/3e5298fa-0ee4-11e7-9518-52ee756506dd.png)

tasks:
```
{
            "taskName": "ChromeRun",
            "isBuildCommand": true,
            "showOutput":"always",
            "command": "Chrome",
            "osx": {
                "command": "/Applications/Google Chrome.app/Contents/MacOS/Google Chrome"
            },
            "args": [
                "${file}"
            ]
        }
```
Now things work well if I Open project at level of geoLocation directory inside vscode, but when I open the folder at root level (as shown in screen shot above) and try to execute tasks, the compiler fails to recognise my task.json file and asks me to create on in root directory (.vscode directory).

Considering the mapping model this is understandable, But what if I want to maintain tasks at each project level, Since all project has different configurations & I don't want all of them to be executed.

(Lack of documentation at https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/tasks routed me this forum, please point to me the more relevant one, in case I am lost).

Thanks much.

data.title: Ripgrep - Can't search for a query that starts with -

data.title: Show JS/TS References Code Lens for Inner Functions
data.body:
From @mhegazy: 

> https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/master/src/compiler/checker.ts 
 
> `createTypeChecker` is our main container function in this file, I would expect inner functions in it to have reference counts, e.g. `function getJsxNamesace`; it is worth noting that enums inside this function are marked, e.g. `const enum TypeSystemPropertyName`.
 
> For locals, I am not so sure, but for example, `const emptyArray = []` this is more of a global/static variable for this function.

data.title: JSDoc comments are ignored for destructured parameters
data.body:
According to https://github.com/jsdoc3/jsdoc/issues/987#issuecomment-93864964, JSDoc for destructured function parameters should be possible:

```js
/**
 * My cool function.
 *
 * @param {Object} obj - An object.
 * @param {string} obj.prop1 - Property 1.
 * @param {string} obj.prop2 - Property 2.
 */
var fn = function ({prop1, prop2}) {
  // Do something with prop1 and prop2
}
```

However, when invoking the function, while Intellisense appears to support properties inside the object param, there is no documentation for individual params inside the destructured object, and the property types are not honored (shown as `any` instead):
![jsdoc-destructuring](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/51629/24177182/ed78261a-0e5d-11e7-8f0c-2b2c32534def.png)

If I set parameter defaults, Intellisense will support those, but will still ignore the types specified in the doc comment (notice that the JSDoc comment is not consistent with the function definition):
![jsdoc-destructuring-defaults](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/51629/24177353/14353170-0e5f-11e7-985c-ce8f0bee1eff.png)

And in both cases, the entire object param is highlighted, but individual params inside it are not.

Is there a different way to write the JSDoc comment, or does support for destructured parameters need to be supported by VS Code as well?

data.title: Add letterSpacing to config to address #18715

data.title: "Find File References"
data.body:
In typescript imports it is possible to ctrl+click to go to the definition of the file, but attempting to "find all references" for the file returns zero results.

This is useful in the instance that you want to rename/delete/majorly refactor a file and want to know all the places that might be affected. If a typescript file exports multiple symbols (classes, interfaces, enums, etc.) it can be a pain to "find all references" for each symbol, but if it worked on the file itself then that would be much easier.

This would of course also be useful for HTML, CSS, and vanilla JS as well.

![findfilereferences](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2957173/24172797/e0347590-0e89-11e7-9c5c-4386b5155407.gif)

data.title: Wacom Intuos Issue (macOS Sierra)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.10.2 (8076a19fdcab7e1fc1707952d652f0bb6c6db331, 2017-03-08T13:56:35.908Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.4.0
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|file-icons|file-icons|1.0.3|
|vscode-auto-open-markdown-preview|hnw|0.0.4|
|spacegray-vscode|ionutvmi|1.1.4|
|svgpreview|kisstkondoros|0.1.2|
|easy-less|mrcrowl|1.3.4|;


---

Using latest Wacom driver (6.3.20-11)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Pen works for several clicks
2. Pen stops functioning properly
3. Pen now can only select text, but acts like it's losing focus and can't control the I-beam anymore.
4. multi-finger gestures also stop working (however, one's middle finger can still be extended at the screen quite happily)
5. Going into the driver in System Preferences allows one to click again in the editor, but only for a few clicks and the cycle repeats (see item 1)

data.title: "Unable to open 'file.c': File not found (c:\code\c:\code\file.c)." when clicking on items in the "Problems" tab
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

Hello everybody. I've set-up my tasks.json to be able to compile my C program using GCC, here it is:

> {
>     // See https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=733558
>     // for the documentation about the tasks.json format
>     "version": "0.1.0",
>     "command": "gcc",
>     "isShellCommand": true,
>     // "args": ["-c"],
>     "showOutput": "always",
>     "suppressTaskName": true,
>     // "options": {
>     //     "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}/build"
>     // },
>     "echoCommand": true,
>     "tasks": [
>         {
>             "taskName": "Build C with GCC",
>             "args" : ["-Wall", "${file}", "-o", "${file}.exe"],
>             "isBuildCommand": true,
>             "problemMatcher": {
>                 "owner": "cpp",
>                 "fileLocation": ["relative", "${workspaceRoot}"],
>                 "pattern": {
>                     "regexp": "^(.*):(\\d+):(\\d+):\\s+(warning|error):\\s+(.*)$",
>                     "file": 1,
>                     "line": 2,
>                     "column": 3,
>                     "severity": 4,
>                     "message": 5
>                 }
>             }
>         }
>     ]
> }

Everything compiles fine when I hit CTRL+SHIFT+B, but if I go to the Problems tab in the bottom panel and hit any existing problems, I'm presented with the following error: 
`Unable to open 'file.c': File not found (c:\code\c:\code\file.c).`

Something seems to be really wrong with the path. The path should be "c:\code\file.c";

Here's an image with the error: http://imgur.com/a/7hFYq

Thanks.

data.title: Matching brackets and very hard to see cursor

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
### Matching brackets and very hard to see cursor

**Description**
So the problem i have, is that its almost impossible to see where your cursor is at, when its on a 
highlighted bracket, resulting in a lot of editing errors.


**Example**

On this first picture, the cursor is on the left side of the bracket:

![cursor-left-side](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/808470/24166734/932edc1e-0e74-11e7-9dff-991c283e5a8f.PNG)

On this picture, the cursor is to the right of the bracket.

![cursor-right-side](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/808470/24166733/932afd10-0e74-11e7-9b8d-556330a6b2f7.PNG)


**Possible Solutions** 

- it should be possible to change color of the bracket highlights, without an extension
- it should be possible to change color of the cursor, without an extension
- the default cursor should be more visible


**System**

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: windows 10

**Steps to Reproduce:**

1. place the cursor at a bracket.
2. try and guess on what side of the bracket the cursor is.

data.title: Pug - Broken syntax coloring using character "" inside an interpolated tag
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.0
- OS Version: Windows 7 ultimate SP1
- Extensions installed:
   - Autoprefixer 2.0.0
   - Pug to HTML 0.0.3
   - SCSS Intellisense 0.6.0

I found a bug in the pug syntax coloring, where if you type a "  " character inside an interpolated string, it makes the text after said character to be colored like a keyword.

**Steps to Reproduce:**

1. In a _.pug_ file, introduce the "  " character inside the text node of an interpolated tag, for instance:

`p The coloring breaks after the #[strong ] character.`

2. The syntax coloring after the "  " character breaks, coloring almost anything like a keyword.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5291103/24163436/5da321c0-0e49-11e7-88c5-8e5ed41f7d87.png)

It happens independently of the color theme applied to the editor, and the bug appears to be only when that specific character is used, you can see that the "  " character in the picture doesn't cause problems in the same circumstances.

data.title: Integrated terminal UI reopens unwanted terminal on startup
data.body:
- VS Code 1.10.2
- Windows 10 Anniversary

With the latest update of the PowerShell extension (0.10.0), we've added a new "PowerShell Integrated Console" that leverages the `createTerminal` API in VS Code.  Users have remarked that when they restart VS Code after using this terminal, the terminal UI starts immediately with their default terminal app before the PowerShell Integrated Console has a chance to load.  More specifically:

1. User starts VS Code without the Terminal panel active
2. User has PowerShell 0.10.0 installed, loads a .ps1 file
3. PowerShell extension loads, creates PowerShell Interactive Console, causing Terminal panel to show
4. User closes VS Code
5. Later, user opens VS Code and the Terminal panel appears at startup, loading their default terminal app (probably powershell.exe)
6. If a .ps1 file is active in the workspace at startup, the "PowerShell Integrated Console" will also be loaded into the Terminal panel

So basically the user ends up having an extra, unwanted process get launched at startup.  I've tried [closing my terminal](https://github.com/PowerShell/vscode-powershell/blob/develop/src/session.ts#L194) at shutdown from my extension's [deactivate function](https://github.com/PowerShell/vscode-powershell/blob/develop/src/main.ts#L135) but even that doesn't prevent the terminal UI from loading upon next startup.

Is there any way I can suppress this additional terminal?

/cc @Tyriar @dotps1

The window doesn't appear when there are already characters there, I think it would be good if it did.

data.title: Make more descriptive appdata summary field
data.body:
This is a small change in the AppData XML file to make the description include Visual Studio Code, which makes it much easier for users to find out the application when browsing e.g. with GNOME Software when a repository containing VSCode is configured. 

Related issue: #22964

---

I am sending this in behalf of @ltilve who has asked me to report the issue and provide the patch on his behalf, as I have already signed the CLA. I hope that's okay.

data.title: Include Visual Studio Code somewhere in the AppData XML
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: `master`
- OS Version: Linux

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Try to search for Visual Studio Code in GNOME Software in a distribution which has a repository configured which includes VSCode.
2. Where is it? :disappointed: 

Currently the AppData XML does not include Visual Studio Code anywhere, so the keywords that users are likely to type for searching won't find the application.

data.title: Can not delete a break point if it's at the last line of code
data.body:
If I set a break point at the last line of code I cannot delete it. My work around is to change where the last line at, for example I press Enter to push down the last line one more new line.

![cannotdeletebreakpoint](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1470309/24158980/79a972e2-0e90-11e7-9d75-7d75e7f7bad8.png)
